Award.AwardTitle: CRII: CPS: Towards an Intelligent Low-Altitude UAS Traffic Management System

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this project is to provide theoretical foundations for cyber-physical systems to support the increasing autonomy in the presence of other manned/unmanned air traffic. Currently the United States air transportation is facing significant challenges due to the rapid evolution of increasingly autonomous systems such as unmanned aircraft systems (UAS) and their expanding presence. However, there has been little scientific investigation on the cyber-physical systems that supports unmanned aircraft operations operating in the presence of other air vehicles. This research project explores novel strategies of coordinating and managing the UAS traffic to ensure low-altitude airspace safety and efficiency in near future. This will also help to catalyze additional cyber-physical systems research in related areas including aviation infrastructures, navigation and surveillance devices, and unmanned aerial vehicle technologies. The investigator will work with Iowa State University Extension and Outreach Office to promote UAS applications in precision agriculture, aviation safety and responsible uses of UAS.

The theoretical aspect of the research will leverage interdisciplinary methodologies in the fields of optimization, artificial intelligence, and control. The project designs algorithms, implements software and demonstrates proof-of-concept using low-altitude UAS traffic management as a challenge application area. This project establishes an unmanned air system traffic simulation platform, which can be used to validate new methods and tools, and enable collaborations with government, industrial and academic partners. The research outcomes are expected to provide a framework to investigate the feasibility, safety, efficiency and potential benefits of the increasing autonomy in civil aviation.

Institution.Name: Iowa State University
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: IOWA STATE UNIVERSITY OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: (1) computational geometry and network optimization models for efficient pre-departure flight plan coordiation; (2) computational guidance algorithm with collision avoidance function for free flight operations; (3) arrival management tools for urban air mobility; and (4) battery discharge prediction model for electric rotorcraft.

Broader Impacts: (1) 4 graduate students were partially supported (one joined USRA to work for NASA Ames); (2) built strong connections with Uber, Airbus, NASA, FAA, Airmap, where several students were mentored or worked as summer interns; (3) PI Wei was invited to work on Airbus' "Blueprint for the Sky: The Roadmap for the Safe Integration of Autonomous Aircraft"; (4) PI Wei was invited as a panelist in 2016 AIAA Aviation UTM Panel; and (5) PI's group continued to participate in ISU Freshman Honor Research Program from 2015 to 2019, advising 20 freshmen during the past 5 years. 

Summary: This project is the first ever funded NSF project for PI Wei, which supported him to establish the foundation in UAS traffic management (UTM) and urban air mobility (UAM), e.g. efficient models and algorithms for pre-departure flight plan coordination and en-route real-time collision avoidance. This award allowed PI Wei obtaining his research reputation and great exposure among government, industry and academia. 3 PhD students and 1 MS student were partially supported by this award along with Prof. Wei's startup funding at Iowa State University. One PhD student has graduated and joined NASA Ames Research Center. 16 conference papers and 1 journal paper were published.
